title: Mother of Blenheim teenager Lara Glover arrived to say goodbye moments before her daughter died at the scene of a car crash
text:
Mother of Blenheim teenager Lara Glover arrived to say goodbye moments before her daughter died at the scene of a car crash JEFFREY KITT Last updated 19:20, February 21 2017 SUPPLIED 
Marlborough Community College student Lara Glover, 16, died in a car crash on Sunday. 
Moments before teenager Lara Glover died, her mother arrived at the crash scene just in time to say "goodbye". 
Blenheim woman Jayne Glover said she was thankful for that one final moment with Lara, who she described as "bubbly and outgoing". 
And the reason she was able to have that moment; a phone call from a family friend who happened to be at the scene when the SUV carrying Lara and seven other teenagers rolled on State Highway 1. SUPPLIED 
The Glover family say they will remember Lara as a "bubbly and outgoing" girl. 
It meant Glover was by her only daughter's side shortly after emergency services arrived. 
READ MORE: 
"I did have that moment, and I will cherish it always," Glover said. SUPPLIED 
A roadside memorial to Blenheim teenager Lara Glover near Spring Creek, north of Blenheim. 
The 16-year-old and her friends were on their way to Picton for a swim when they crashed near Spring Creek, about 8 kilometres north of Blenheim, on Sunday. 
They ranged in age from 15 to 17 and three were still in hospital. 
The crash had forever changed each of the young lives but nobody was to blame, Glover said. 
"They all have to live with the fact they had an accident which resulted in my daughter's death, I don't want them to carry a burden for their whole life," she said. 
"There's no blame, this was an accident." 
The fallout of the accident was felt on social media and it was upsetting to see people point fingers, Glover said. SCOTT HAMMOND/FAIRFAX NZ 
The serious crash unit investigates the cause of the fatal accident north of Blenheim. 
"That reaction disgusted me, it's appalling how people can do that without knowing the details and just assume," she said. 
"It made me angry. My daughter didn't die for someone to get crucified for it. 
"My message is for these kids to be safe and kind to each other. Look out for one another because you never know, this could happen to anybody." 
Lara was the youngest of seven children in the Glover family, with six brothers. 
Her mum said they shared a special bond. FAIRFAX NZ 
A SUV carrying eight teenagers rolled on State Highway 1 near Spring Creek on Sunday. 
"We had a great rapport. She was very bubbly and outgoing. She made people laugh," she said. 
"Now it's all about looking to the future, Lara would have wanted that. 
"From all of our family, our heartfelt thoughts are with the kids who are still in hospital." 
A funeral service would be held for Lara at the Mayfield Chapel, in Blenheim, on Friday.
